english: paid on-demand errand and same-city delivery services

etymology.description: 跑(跑) (pǎo, "run") and 腿(腿) (tuǐ, "leg") together describe the act of running errands.
etymology.interpretation: The term 跑腿(跑腿) (pǎo tuǐ) conveys the idea of someone using their legs to 'run' or carry out errands for others, often as a service. This makes sense as a metaphor for quick, on-demand delivery or errand running, where the 'running' signifies speed and activity.

examples.chinese: 我昨天请人跑腿送文件(我昨天請人跑腿送文件)。
examples.pinyin: Wǒ zuótiān qǐng rén pǎo tuǐ sòng wénjiàn.
examples.english: Yesterday, I hired someone to run an errand to deliver documents.

examples.chinese: 她用跑腿服务买了新鲜蔬菜(她用跑腿服務買了新鮮蔬菜)，节省了时间(節省了時間)。
examples.pinyin: Tā yòng pǎo tuǐ fúwù mǎile xīnxiān shūcài, jiéshěngle shíjiān.
examples.english: She used the on-demand errand service to buy fresh vegetables, which saved time.

examples.chinese: 在忙碌的下午(在忙碌的下午)，跑腿成为必备服务(跑腿成為必備服務)。
examples.pinyin: Zài mánglù de xiàwǔ, pǎo tuǐ chéngwéi bìbèi fúwù.
examples.english: During a busy afternoon, errand running becomes an essential service.
